intro: Cheiranthus apricus, commonly known as the spring flowering wallflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and basal leaves that are lance-shaped. Its flowers, which range in color from yellow to orange, bloom in early spring, often before the leaves fully develop. The plant is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in rocky or sandy environments.
